story:
Un livre pour pyratiser votre carrière!

Vous aimez Go Pyrate! et les concepts et valeurs que défendent Olivier et Maurice?

Le Manuel du Pyrate se veut un guide pratique apportant des concepts pouvant être mis en pratique immédiatement, et qui vous permettront de regagner le contrôle de votre vie professionnelle. 

Personne ne vous fera de cadeau, et il n'y a que VOUS qui puissiez reprendre le rênes de votre propre carrière:

  • Pyratisez votre Expertise: Votre expertise est votre armement, alors apprenez à développer efficacement la bonne expertise pour vous, et faites-la évoluer constamment. 
  • Pyratisez votre Impact: Tous les efforts ne sont pas égaux! Apprenez à obtenir la maximum d'impact pour chacune de vos action, tout en éliminant ou transformant le travail n'apportant que peu de valeur. 
  • Pyratisez votre Influence: Utilisez votre expertise pour développer une solide réputation auprès de votre réseau et de vos co-équipiers. Développer influence et apprenez à vendre vos idées comme un capitaine.
  • Pyratisez votre Leadership: Adoptez les techniques permettant de libérer le potentiel des gens autour de vous, donner une vision et direction commune et atteindre vos objectifs. 

 

Par les Pyrates, pour les Pyrates! 

Go Pyrate! est un organisme à but non-lucratif, rassemblant les pyrates de ce monde.

  • Ce sont nos pyrates qui ont clamé haut et fort pour un manuel pratique.
  • Ce sont nos pyrates qui ont choisi les sujets couverts.

story:
For its third book, Letterform Archive is proud to announce Only on Saturday, a stunning tribute to Jack Stauffacher, a letterpress printer, typographer, and designer whose elegant and innovative type treatments cemented his reputation as one of the best printers of the twentieth century.

 

 

Only on Saturday is the only comprehensive look at Stauffacher’s striking typographic experiments, in which he used a box of worn, mismatched wood type to transform letters from legibility workhorses into expressive studies of surface, color, and form. 

These prized compositions — some patterned with letters in different sizes, typefaces, and inks; some layered with multiple presses of a single letter; others awash in solvent — morphed from exploratory pieces made during his off hours into formal studies of what was possible between the positive and negative spaces on a page. Toward the end of his life, Stauffacher expressed that these prints were “experimental up to a point”: a series of investigations that, once complete, yielded a deliberate statement of design. Today, they are in the permanent collections of many major museums. 

 

ma5 series prints, Jack Stauffacher, 1969. Collection of Letterform Archive.

 

Edited and designed by Chuck Byrne (a years-long contributor to PRINT magazine and Stauffacher’s longtime friend and representative in the art world), Only on Saturday:

  • will be the first widely distributed book on AIGA medalist Jack Stauffacher; 
  • features hundreds of his wood type prints — many of which have never before been shared in book form — all imaged and printed using the highest reproduction standards in a handsome, large-format art book;
  • provides an unprecedented look at Stauffacher’s process, presented through in-progress materials recovered from his studio;
  • thoroughly documents Stauffacher’s influences, from his early days in the California letterpress scene to his absorption of modernist and Swiss Style teachings;
  • includes insights from established names in type like Chuck Bigelow, Matthew Carter, and Jim Faris; representatives of the modern art world such as Jennifer Dunlop Fletcher, SFMOMA curator, and Staci Steinberger, LACMA associate curator; and a host of his closest friends and collaborators, including photographer Dennis Letbetter. 

 

Prints from the Vico Wooden Letters portfolio, Jack Stauffacher, 2003. Collection of Letterform Archive.

 

HOW YOU CAN HELP 

Your pledge for Only on Saturday will share Jack Stauffacher’s important artwork and charming story with the world. While we have already invested heavily in the book’s development, your support will cover production costs and enable Letterform Archive to digitize our complete collection of Stauffacher prints, freezing their details — their color, type impression, and paper texture — in high-resolution reproductions that will be enjoyed for generations.

 

 

The regular (left) and deluxe (right) editions of Only on Saturday.

THE BOOK

A Choice of Two Editions Only on Saturday is available in two editions: regular, a hardcover design featuring one of Stauffacher’s experimental press sheets and a jacket artfully wrapped with a full-bleed image from his book At Hand . . . 

 


The regular edition, with its jacket unfolded.

 

... and deluxe, a hardcover plus a portfolio containing 10 offset facsimile prints and 10 letterpress proofs created with Stauffacher’s actual wood type. The book and portfolio are housed in a slipcase, and all three are covered in Stauffacher’s favorite raw silk. 

 


The deluxe edition, with its slipcase and portfolio of letterpress wood type proofs and offset facsimile prints.

 

Created at the Berkeley print shop of esteemed printer and Stauffacher’s friend Peter Koch, the portfolio’s 10 letterpress wood type proofs offer fans the unique chance to own impressions made using his actual wood type — with all of their formal magic and special surface imperfections clearly visible on the page.

 


The portfolio of the deluxe edition of Only on Saturday, with the letterpress wood type proofs on the left and offset facsimile prints on the right.

 

The Story Only on Saturday examines five limited-edition portfolios of Stauffacher’s prints, as well as his individual monoprints and series prints. For each major body of work, a selection of images is paired with a first-person essay from one of Stauffacher’s collaborators, who together paint a portrait of a printer-scholar at the top of his craft. 

Only on Saturday also features an in-depth essay by Chuck Byrne that traces the printer’s influences and artistic development. Byrne takes us from Stauffacher’s first encounters with California letterpress printers, to his introduction to the modernist principles of Piet Mondrian and László Moholy-Nagy, to his time in Basel with famed Swiss designers Jan Tschichold and Emil Ruder, whose deliberations about typography helped Stauffacher see the page as a space fit for experimental typographic meditations. 

The Contributors Kristina Bell · John D. Berry · Chuck Bigelow · Chuck Byrne · Matthew Carter · Stephen Coles · Jim Faris · Jennifer Dunlop Fletcher · Nathan Garland · Dennis Letbetter · Staci Steinberger · Michael Taylor · Pino Trogu 

 


Matthew Carter’s essay in Only on Saturday.

 

The Design Lovingly laid out by Chuck Byrne as an homage to Stauffacher, Only on Saturday features a spare, elegant design and Jack’s favorite typeface: Kis. 

 


A gallery spread of thumbnails from the Vico Wooden Letters portfolio, a collaboration with photographer Dennis Letbetter, in Only on Saturday.
 

The Photographs Imaged with raking light and a 100-megapixel Phase One camera in Letterform Archive’s photography studio, the original artwork in Only on Saturday is of the highest possible reproduction quality. Each image was soft-proofed against the original artwork to ensure a 100-percent color match. 

Many friends and colleagues also contributed portraits of the artist himself, with special thanks to photographer and collaborator Dennis Letbetter for allowing us to include his treasure trove of Stauffacher imagery.

 


A spread from Only on Saturday, with a large reproduction of a print from the Vico Wooden Letters portfolio.

 

Book Specifications 14 by 10 inches · 208 pages · 30,000 words · 250 images · Printed with UV drying

 


Prints from The Wood Letters of the Greenwood Press portfolio, Jack Stauffacher, 1975. Collection of SFMOMA.

 

LETTERFORM ARCHIVE’S STAUFFACHER COLLECTION

As a nonprofit center for design inspiration, education, and community, Letterform Archive holds an extensive collection of original prints by Jack Stauffacher, including many eye-opening pieces that illustrate his process and tell the story of his remarkable work’s genesis. Discovered when Letterform Archive curators assisted with cleaning out Stauffacher’s studio of 50 years at 300 Broadway, this process work helps us understand the methodical yet inspired thinking behind his typographic designs. 

Housed in our collection of 50,000+ graphic design and typography samples gathered from across the history of written language, Stauffacher’s work demonstrates a fundamental tenet of Letterform Archive’s philosophy: that such meditative and playful experiments in type deserve to be treated as art. 

 


G series prints, Jack Stauffacher, date unknown. Collection of Letterform Archive.

 

ABOUT JACK STAUFFACHER

Born in 1920 in San Mateo, California, Jack Stauffacher was a printer, typographer, and fine-book publisher whose delicate yet bold sensibility landed his work in library rare book collections and later in museums, which sought out his typographic prints.

 


Stauffacher with his wife Josephine while on a Fulbright fellowship in Italy, circa 1955. 

 

A printer of exceptional skill who began his apprenticeship as a teenager, Stauffacher created books for his Greenwood Press off and on for eight decades. He also traveled to Italy on a Fulbright scholarship to learn from European master printers, taught typography at Carnegie Tech (now Carnegie Mellon) and the San Francisco Art Institute, and served as typographic director at Stanford University Press. Undeterred by new technologies, Stauffacher also advised Adobe as they undertook reviving classic typefaces for digital use in the 1980s. 

 


Stauffacher in his office at Carnegie Tech, circa 1960. Image courtesy Fritz Klinke.

 

But it was his later wood type prints that shifted his career into the realm of fine art, and that make up the subject of this book. Stauffacher created these prints — which he called “typographic meditations” — from 1966 until his death in 2017 at the age of 96. As recognition of his contributions to typography and design, he was awarded an AIGA medal in 2004. 

Today, Stauffacher’s work is in the permanent collections of major museums such as SFMOMA, LACMA, and the Denver Museum of Art. In addition, the Bancroft Library at UC Berkeley holds a large collection of the papers, books, and portfolios of Stauffacher’s Greenwood Press, while Stanford University’s Special Collections and University Archives also has a substantial collection of his materials.

 


Jack Stauffacher at the AIGA annual conference in 2003. Image courtesy Larry Will.

 

In addition to his legendary craftsmanship, Stauffacher is remembered today as a spirited character who founded a lively community of philosophers, printers, and artists, and made an indelible stamp on the intellectual landscape of San Francisco.

Below is a clip of some of Stauffacher’s long-time San Francisco friends and collaborators reminiscing about him.

 

 

Praise for Jack Stauffacher

“The last of San Francisco’s traditional bohemians of the 1930s, Stauffacher became known as an articulate participant in the local literary and artistic avant-garde, as well as an inspiring mentor for young people and newcomers to the Bay Area. . . . [He was] the dean of San Francisco printers.” San Francisco Chronicle

“As typographers, designers, and printers, we translate words into written communication. Jack had done that all his life, making words visible. Then, after he had designed pretty much everything worth designing for a purpose, he started doing the opposite: he picked random wood letters from a case he had stumbled upon and made images with them. We aren’t supposed to read those letters as words but to go back to where they came from: pictures of those things. A large red B can be a sail, a blue A on its side is the sea, and the little black letters are birds or stones or ripples. . . . When I asked Jack about the prints, he said that those letters had become such intimate friends over time that he could behold them just as beautiful objects; they didn’t have to work for a living anymore.” Erik Spiekermann

“Jack was a very special person: easy to meet, hard to fathom, fun to be with, stimulating to listen to, effortless to learn from, and difficult to forget. . . . His cheerful and gentlemanly demeanor masked a determination to think and work at the highest level. His modern old-fashionedness found its way into everything he did and provided me with yet another model of how to live a fulfilling life in design.” Chris Pullman, Design Observer

“Jack Stauffacher . . . spent his long career in an intimate relationship with typographic form, content, and the craft of assembling letters — one at a time — to create beautiful and meaningful communications that will be relevant five-hundred years from now.” Terry Irwin

 


Prints from The Rebel Albert Camus portfolio, Jack Stauffacher, 1969. Collection of Letterform Archive.

 

ADDITIONAL REWARDS 

 

PROJECT CREDITS


Author Chuck Byrne with Jack Stauffacher at the Bonnafont Gallery, 1998. Image courtesy Dennis Letbetter.

Chuck Byrne (author and designer) is a writer and designer based in the San Francisco Bay Area. His graphic design work has appeared in Communication Arts, Idea, ID, and Graphis 
magazines, and he served as a contributing editor and writer for PRINT magazine for more than a decade. He has also been on the graphic design faculty of San Jose State University, California College of the Arts, and the University of Cincinnati.

Byrne met Jack Stauffacher in 1989 and quickly became a regular at the printer’s celebrated Friday lunches, at which friends with wide-ranging backgrounds in the arts would come together to share ideas. In 1998, Byrne penned an influential cover story for Emigre magazine on Stauffacher’s work, introducing him to a new generation of design and typography enthusiasts, and he has long served as an ambassador and unofficial spokesperson for his work in the design community at large.

Rob Saunders (publisher) is a designer, teacher, and management consultant with a lifelong interest in the letter arts. Saunders taught at the Boston Museum School, then published graphic design and children’s books through the Alphabet Press, Picture Book Studio, and Rabbit Ears Books imprints. After 40 years of collecting graphic design and lettering, he founded Letterform Archive to make the collection available to students, designers, and admirers of the letter arts.

Lucie Parker (associate publisher) has 15 years’ experience crafting best-selling and award-winning books for the trade and gift markets. She specializes in producing design-driven titles, often in collaboration with museums and magazines.

With expert support from the Letterform Archive publishing team, Chris Westcott and Molly O’Neil Stewart.

 


Proofs from The Wooden Letters of 300 Broadway portfolio, Jack Stauffacher, 1998. Collection of Letterform Archive.

 


2 series prints, Jack Stauffacher, date unknown. Collection of Letterform Archive.

 

PRODUCTION SCHEDULE

  • Files provided to the printer: December 31, 2019
  • Book goes on press: January 31, 2020
  • Book arrives in warehouse: May 1, 2020
  • Book delivered to backers: June 1, 2020

 


Left to right: Monoprint with broken M (1980) and two process explorations with broken M (circa 1998), Jack Stauffacher. Collection of Letterform Archive.

 


 


Process work for Tsunami print, Jack Stauffacher, 2013. Collection of Letterform Archive.

 

Risks and challenges

This book has been thoughtfully researched and written, expertly designed, and superbly imaged. It is in the late stages of layout, editing, and color correction. Chuck Byrne has designed dozens of books in his career, and his expertise — combined with the extensive publishing experience of the team at Letterform Archive and the successful delivery of our first two books, W. A. Dwiggins: A Life in Design and Morla : Design — ensures the success of this project. We see very little risk for backers.

Author Bio and Inspiration

Karen Fournier is a mother of three daughters whose life took a turn when all three became suicidal at various points since 2016.  Each one suffered from severe depression. One daughter suffered crippling panic attacks.  Another wrote goodbye letters to those she loved.  Another attempted suicide twice in the span of two months, and nearly died both times.  Fortunately, all three survived and are on the road to healing.  (Please watch the video for more on the family's emotional journey.)

Karen has transformed her family’s pain into a mission to help parents whose children are struggling with anxiety, depression, and/or suicidal ideation, through education and support. 

Karen's book,  Helpless Night, Hopeful Dawn: Staying Positive and Proactive When Your Child is Suicidal,  has been written for parents whose children are struggling with depression or suicidal ideation.  The book includes:

-- a personal memoir of her fight to keep her daughters alive,

-- practical advice to other parents going through the same ordeal,

-- education on suicide, online influences, bullying, and child abuse,

-- anti-suicide resources, 

-- a self-reflection section for parents, and

-- passages written by her daughters: what it’s like to feel suicidal and what helped to get them through it. 

The book will be released in spring of 2021.

Other Parts of This Mission

A Podcast:  Empowered Parenting for Emotional Wellness -  featuring mental-health and wellness experts, for parents interested in supporting their sons’ and daughters’ optimal mental health and well-being.  Listeners will learn to recognize and address mental-health concerns, ideally before they become major sources of dysfunction.   Some of the topics include trauma, abuse, bullying, anxiety, grief, loss, gender differences in emotional expression, emotional support animals, holistic approaches, and much more. Karen has a BA in psychology and has worked as a gifted/talented teacher, a counselor in a group home for emotionally disturbed boys, a tutor in a psychiatric hospital, and a video producer who has interviewed over 600 people in her career.  This will launch in December 2020.

Shine the Light Scholarship - a percentage of funds from the book sales will be donated to:

1. Anti-suicide programs, and

2. Scholarships so that suicidal children without insurance can partake in intensive-outpatient (IOP) or partial hospitalization (PHP) programs which employ Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT).  DBT programs provide coping skills to combat emotional stressors and have high success rates in curtailing suicidal ideation.  (Two of Karen’s daughters participated in IOP and PHP programs, which were life-changing for both of them.)  The goal is to help change the trajectory of suicidal ideation and to combat our nation’s suicide epidemic, one life at a time.

Funding:

The money from this Indiegogo will be used to fund:

-- Developmental editing, round 1   (September 2020)

-- Book cover Design (October, 2020)

-- Branding  (October, 2020)

-- Developmental editing, round 2  (December 2020)

-- Copy and line editing  (January/February 2021)

-- Research assistance for the book's educational components (November 2020 - February, 2021)

-- Web site for book, blog, and parent resources (January, 2020)

-- Book design - interior  (February 2021)

-- Book formatting (Kindle and print)   (March 2021)

-- Converting the book to audiobook format (April, 2021)

-- Marketing support for maximum outreach and impact  (March 2021 onward)

The Impact

Suicide rates are at an all-time high!  According to the National Institute of Mental Health:

-- Suicide is the second-leading cause of death in individuals between the ages of 10 and 34.

-- The total suicide rate in the United States has increased 35% in the last 20 years alone.

-- 800,000 people die by suicide each year (one every 40 seconds).

Depression has weighed our children down, precipitated by numerous family and societal stressors.  Parents are struggling to keep their children above board.  In addition, the stress from dealing with an emotionally unstable child can deeply affect the rest of the family and create unstable conditions in the home. 

This book will give help and hope to parents who are dealing with these incredibly difficult circumstances.

A Special Note from the Author

Having gone through terrible ordeals with my own suicidal children, I am inspired to overcome any possible obstacles in an effort to reach out to others, and to support these struggling children and their families.

I believe that education is a powerful force to fight against the stressors which threaten to bring our children down into depression.  Our children deserve to live healthy and happy lives.

This is my mission, and this is my heart.

Karen Fournier

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign to friends, family, and your online groups. Please feel free to use the Indiegogo share buttons!  

THANK YOU FOR SUPPORTING THIS IMPORTANT MISSION!

story:
The Biography:


Home Grown In Marin
The Sons of Champlin
A Bay Area Music Odyssey


Odyssey: An epic journey usually marked by many changes of fortune. 


To me, when looking back over the career of The Sons of Champlin, a few things stand out in particular. First, is the band’s incredible longevity. The Sons have been playing together, notwithstanding various personnel changes, and several hiatuses, for more than 50 years, an amazing feat any way you cut it. Equally impressive is that over this time they never reverted to anything resembling a “greatest hits” or tribute band, and have continued moving forward with new arrangements, innovations and material all the way through. 

Next, of near or equal interest to many of the group’s loyal fans is discovering a reasonable explanation to the puzzling question of why, in light of their consistently top level artistic talent, The Sons never achieved greater commercial success. Both of these questions require complex explanations, and are central to the documentation of the band’s story in this biography.

And finally, from a historical standpoint especially, one of the more interesting facets of The Sons’ long and curious career is the fact that it spanned two significant periods in the developmental history of rock and roll music. Coming of age in rock's still parochial formative years, the early Sons of Champlin were among the multitudes of bands hoping to land gigs for what were then considered sizable crowds of perhaps 200 fans. For them and so many other like minded young rock musicians forming groups during the early 1960s, among the many changes witnessed during the ensuing decade was the monumental increase, both literally and figuratively, in the level of opportunities to play and be heard. In many ways it was a perfect confluence of the country’s growing economy, (including what would become huge opportunities for the entertainment business), and the enormous social and political challenges that were becoming focal points for a youth generation of unprecedented numbers. As the decade continued to unfold, many of these youngsters were becoming increasingly convinced that this country, indeed the world, could be a better place if everyone were to take stock and work together for much needed and necessary change.

Rock music’s increasing level of thematic emphasis on personal liberation and consciousness raising was directly addressing this growing sense of possibility for the future. Its expressive power and energy, indeed its musicality, thrust the music into a central unifying role in the emerging perspective, both reflecting and fueling a world view that was capturing the imagination and optimism of a generation. And the Sons of Champlin were right there in the middle of it, sounding a call that helped to propel this music into something more far reaching and influential than anyone then could ever have imagined.

Can you feel it coming?
It’s gonna set you back on your heels.
It’s gonna sound like humming
And you’ll believe in how good it feels.

1982-A, Loosen Up Naturally (1969)
--The Sons of Champlin

Among the established bands and performers coming out of Marin County in the late 1950s and early 60s were the trailblazing Kustom Keys, legendary Marin rock and roll pioneer, John Allair, the Swingin’ Deacons with John Cippolina (later of Quicksilver Messenger Service), the Chord Lords, and the precursor to the Sons of Champlin, the Opposite Six, featuring Bill Champlin, Tim Cain, Rob Moitoza and ultimately Terry Haggerty. All of these groups were laying the foundation for the region’s reputation as a center for top notch talent. And at the same time by booking, in particular, the younger of these fledgling bands to play in local school auditoriums and recreational centers, a growing contingent of vibrant entrepreneurial newcomers, including the likes of Marin teenager Ed Margoliash, were actively gaming for the fertile profit making potential of baby-boomer fans clamoring to hear the music they loved. And just across the Golden Gate Bridge was the remarkably industrious Bill Graham, who would become central to the development of San Francisco's music scene and forever alter how rock music was promoted and marketed to American youth.

On another front, unprecedented economic prosperity following WWII portended a dramatic increase in the amount of discretionary money available to the period’s youth, particularly those of the white middle class, and became a driving force behind the sharp increase in not only the interest in the music by the recording industry, but also the corresponding rise in radio stations gearing up to satisfy the appetites of those searching for access to rock and roll. And ultimately, with the emergence of the youth counterculture, particularly in mid-1960s San Francisco, pioneering music promoters such as Chet Helms and the enterprising Graham began revolutionizing local concert productions to accommodate not only the growing number of quality bands but the legions of fans wanting to see them perform. Arriving in San Francisco early in the decade and searching for inroads into the artistic landscape, both Graham and Helms by 1966 had opened the doors to such historic venues as the Fillmore Auditorium, Winterland and the Avalon Ballroom, sites that would establish the gold standard for rock concerts everywhere during the period. And from the very start, a core mainstay on the rosters of musicians hired to play these hallowed halls were The Sons of Champlin. 

In many ways, it is this status that reflects the importance and relevance of The Sons to the Bay Area music scene of the 60s and 70s. They were always in the mix, always in the game, and consistently produced the kind of quality music that earned the deep respect of not only their fan base but of their musical peers across the board. This is a fact. And as such, it can be argued that The Sons are a perfect lens through which to view the musical and cultural developments of the period.  

Going into this project, it was understood that this band’s history was a complex and complicated one, as most powerful artistic collaborations are. I can remember early in the going, Champlin telling me that depending on which side of the stage you were on, the experience could be a very different one. Engaging in the long series of interviews and conversations with band members and others in the mix has borne this out. And although there was initial reticence on the part of some members of the group, especially when asked to weigh in on more personal matters, we soon established the level of personal trust between writer and subject that authentic and reliable documentations require.

As with all good histories, this biography is more than simply an overview of the music. It is also a profile of the diverse and unique personalities and talents involved, all framed within the context of what was happening musically and culturally in the times and places where it all transpired. In doing the necessary research and interview work to this point, I am more convinced than ever that bringing this history to life is very much worth the effort and that everyone involved, from band members to the fan base, will be pleased and gratified with the end product. 

The Story Behind The Story

My name is Joe Mathews and I was born in San Francisco in 1952. I grew up on the mid-peninsula, graduated in 1970 from Woodside High School in Redwood City, and after completing a BS and MA in 1975, became a high school history teacher, spending much of my professional life in public education. Since 1995 I have been writing biographical oral history, including a collection underwritten by the National Endowment for the Humanities titled, California Rhythm and Blues Music: 1945-1955, portions of which are archived in the Bancroft Library at the University of California at Berkeley and the Smithsonian Institute in Washington D.C. Since that time I have published additional biographical histories as well as work for a variety of journals and periodicals.

As a youngster, music was an integral part of life around our family home. With my dad being a pretty serious music buff, we always had a reliable stream of tunes pouring out of the hi-fi, priming all of us kids on the swing era bands and jazz greats from the 1930s, 40s, and 50s. But for me, the watershed year was 1957, when at age 5, I first heard Little Richard’s, “Keep a Knockin”, from which point onward I became forever captivated by the sounds of the great rock and roll, soul, and R&B masters of the day. Access to it all was flowing from local Bay Area Top 40 AM radio stations that began broadcasting in the late 1950s, including San Francisco stalwarts KEWB, KYA and KFRC, San Jose’s KLIV, and Oakland’s soul music flagship, the “Lucky 13”, KDIA. From then on, my ears were wide open to everything coming over the airwaves, including from the old clock radio anchored at the head of my bed that found me regularly tuning in until way past when it was assumed the lights were out for the night.  And so began the steady diet that was going to fuel my musical interests for decades to come. I just couldn’t get enough of it. To this day, I can easily recall the ten-year-old boy eagerly laying out his hard saved $12 for the shiny new transistor radio in the local drug store’s display case, enabling me to travel with the music at all times. 

As I grew into a dedicated fan of the likes of soul greats James Brown, and the monster performers from Stax and Motown, I fell in love with the integrated power of the back beat and the groove, the dynamic arranging, sweet horn sections, and the knock-out singing that was coming from the wide array of these mostly black artists of the day. Like so many of you that were similarly taken by their energy and dynamism, these tunes served as a daily source of vitality and inspiration for me, made even more powerful against the backdrop of the rapidly changing racial awareness sweeping across the country at the time. 

By no means any less captivating in its own right, was the tidal wave of great music coming from so many other groups and performers around the country, not to mention the surge from across the Atlantic once the British Invasion kicked in. Listening to my trusty radio as I waited for the school bus, I can distinctly remember hearing the Beatles’ “I Want To Hold Your Hand” for the first time and thinking, “Wow, what good song. Who are these guys?” Same thing upon first hearing the Stones’ cover of “Not Fade Away”, whose interpretations of the blues from a continent away were ironically introducing this bedrock American art form to a whole new generation of young kids in this country, me included. It was a fabulously unrelenting current of talent and new songs that were being aired by radio station DJ’s every single week. Scores of new bands were cranking out so many memorable tunes (check out the 1964 TAMI show event filmed live from the Santa Monica Civic Auditorium for a quick reminder of the amazing artistic array that was routinely available over the airwaves).

And right here in the Bay Area was something else, right? In addition to regional musical pillars such as The Grateful Dead, Jefferson Airplane, Big Brother, Cold Blood, Quicksilver, Santana, Sly and the Family Stone, and more, an abundance of sounds were proliferating from a host of other local bands such as  The Count V, Sydicate of Sound, Beau Brummels, and The Seeds. The excitement surrounding the new music and records was everywhere and simply impossible to ignore, and it seemed as though new listening revelations were always just around the corner. Any chance you remember putting The Electric Flag’s “Long Time Comin'" on the turntable and hearing “Killing Floor” for the first time? Man, it felt as if nothing better in the universe could possibly be rolling through life at that point. Add to that the advent of FM radio’s trailblazing KMPX and KSAN, the slates of live shows happening every weekend at San Francisco’s storied venues and so many others around the Bay, and you’ve got a music culture that was steamrolling into something positively magical. To this day when I look back on those times, I have to marvel at my good fortune of having been around for the incredible artistry and talent that was arriving on a seemingly daily basis. It was an amazing thing to behold and I am so grateful to have been a witness to it.

It was in the midst of this “best of all worlds” musical environment that I heard The Sons of Champlin’s Loosen Up Naturally for the first time. With its blazing R&B driven power and the lightning bolt urgency of its personalized message, I was pretty much floored right off. I can remember thinking, "Man, what a band. Where in the world did their grip on it come from?" Well, several listenings in and that was it for me, and from that point onward, I was dialed in to whatever was coming up next. I have to say, that as a thoroughly impressionable adolescent at the time, it was not only the great playing and arrangements that got me, but the deep and incisive quality of the lyrical content that spoke to the broadening of one’s outlook on the world. So much of it pointed to the possibility of a more unrestrained,  generous, and benevolent society, where all one needed to advance the cause was to seize the optimism and engage in becoming better human beings. Great stuff. 

And from there, the band continued to remain in step with popular culture, and doing what art reliably does, the Sons continued moving creatively onward with the flow, while never abandoning their definitive R&B roots. They proceeded to produce six more LPs, including their 1973 masterpiece, Welcome to the Dance, which by all that is right in the world should have put them squarely in the center of the national rock music conversation. Based on artistic merit, both musically and lyrically, by all accounts this album was the equal to most anything in the genre coming out of the record industry at the time. Underscoring their stature by this point, Bill Graham introduced the Sons on a fall 1974 evening at Winterland by righteously proclaiming; “These gentlemen have been around as long as we have, and thank God for that. From Marin, The Sons of Champlin.” Oh, yeah.

After concluding that nothing comprehensive had ever been written on The Sons’ long and fascinating history, I decided to reach out to Bill and ask if he might  be interested in doing a documentation of this kind. He agreed to meet at his home in Los Angeles, and after an afternoon of lively conversation he decided that this was something he very much wanted to see happen. From there I reached out to the other guys, and here we are.

Where will the money go?

All the funding generated from this campaign will go directly towards underwriting the remaining travel requirements, editing, proofreading, rewards, supplies and support staff to complete the project. The most pressing financial need is meeting the enormous burden of transcribing the interview content. Once the project was embraced by the band members and began gathering momentum, the stream of personal referrals and related research discoveries began to create a substantial source base. And because this is an oral biography, there are still close to a hundred hours of required interview material that has yet to be transcribed. But despite the host of challenges ahead, you can rest assured that our team has the drive, the talent and the skill to take it where it needs to go from here, and with your support we will make it happen.

Budget Breakdown:

Project Goal Total: $22,000

Interview Transcription: 31%

Travel: 17%

Video/Photo : 5%

Editing: 12%

Web Support: 10%

Creative Design: 7%

Contributor Rewards: 5%

Indigogo Costs: 5%

 

Risks and Challenges:

From the project’s inception, I have undertaken total responsibility for underwriting the effort. As explained earlier, biographical projects such as this one have a tendency to grow due to the increasing numbers of people becoming involved. Because of this natural expansion, the logistical and economic requirements have done likewise, creating a financially unsustainable scenario moving forward. It is because I have exhausted the available funding to continue underwriting the project on my own, that I am appealing to you here for additional help. All contributions are enormously valuable to us and will be acknowledged for their generosity. On this note, please do what you can to advance the cause by referring this link to all you are aware of who might be interested. As you know, I am firmly committed to completing this book, and with your help, we will surely make it happen. Speaking for myself and everyone who contributes to the campaign, I know we will all come away with a deep satisfaction from having been a part of it. So again, thank you all so very much.


Get In Touch!

Speaking from one Sons fan to another, I would love to hear from you regarding your own special memories, recollections and assorted Sons experiences. Perhaps there was a particular show, venue or maybe even crossing paths with band members along the way. In addition to interesting stories, if you have access to photos, posters or other related printed material, even audio that you came across over the years, I would very much appreciate your getting back to me. Thanks in advance, and be sure to include your contact information so that I can respond.
Contact Joe Mathews at: ajmathews2@gmail.com

Check out the Perks Below...

Once making the decision to launch this fundraising effort, I wanted to be sure to provide the kinds of “perk” rewards/incentives that I might enjoy receiving myself. As such, I have decided to offer the options below to all of you who wish to help us out. Thanks to everyone for your generous support.


1. Original Sons Logo, 1974 (12”x12”)

The classic Sons of Champlin logo was originally designed and painted (watercolor) by Dick Moore for the 1975 self-titled album. Dick has graciously agreed to sign some prints for contributors to the campaign.

 

2. Bill Champlin, 1965 (12”x18”)

Here, a seventeen-year-old Bill Champlin leans in for a vocal at an Opposite Six rehearsal in February, 1965. This photo was on the cover page for a feature story that appeared in the Marin Independent Journal that year on the band that included future core members of the Sons of Champlin. At certain contribution levels, you can acquire a signed 12"x18" print of this unique photo for your home.

3. Sons Concert Poster, 1977 (12”x 18”)


 

Bring it, Terry! For an appropriate contribution you can acquire a 12"x18" print of this very rare Sons of Champlin concert promotion poster from 1977 featuring an electrified Terry Haggerty playing his vintage Gibson L-5. How cool would this look hanging from your wall?

4. Sons Of Champlin Biography Book Cover (12”x18”)

Sons logo creator, Dick Moore, and his long-time partner and fellow graphic artist, Ann Thomson, designed this handsome cover for the upcoming biography of the Sons of Champlin. Author Joe Mathews will sign it if requested.

5. Sons Coffee Mug

You can welcome the new day everyday with your own Breakfast Special Sons Logo Coffee Mug. Cheers to all the good things to come!

6. “Got Sons?” Bumper Sticker

Required material for every Sons fan, this high quality gloss finish bumper sticker is yours at every level of contribution. It's an easy and effective shout-out  to one of our all-time favorite bands!

7. Men’s Sons Logo T-Shirt

For the guys we're offering these handsome Sons Logo t-shirts, available in a range of sizes.


8. Women’s Sons Logo T-Shirt

For the ladies we've got these sharp looking style cut Sons Logo t-shirts, available in a range of sizes.

story:
Hi, I'm Jo Dibblee. I’m best known for my philanthropic work in Canada, USA, and Mexico and for being an animal lover. For as far back as I can remember, I have lived my life in service to animals and humans. But at the center of my love for animals are dogs.

When we adopted Bella, a Border Collie Miniature Schnauzer mix, she was tiny and grossly underweight due to her mother’s lack of milk. Bella weighed only two pounds.

Jo Dibblee with Bella and her siblings

The connection was instant – Bella adopted us. It was love, at first sight, on the night she scrambled up into my lap. And although Bella was pint-sized, she commanded attention gently and lovingly.

Bella at one year

 

Bella's life was far too short, but she changed our world and all who came to know her in unusual ways no one could ever have expected.

Bella saved my husband's life - all before she was even two years old. A retired firefighter Michael struggled with PTSD. If not for Bella the story would be very different.

The vast majority of first responders: Firefighters, Paramedics, EMTs, Police, and those whose careers are in the Military, Doctors, Veterinarians, Nurses, and sadly the list goes on, all are at significant risk of developing either ASD or PTSD. 

But anxiety disorders are not restricted to the above careers—so many are suffering in silence. 

Without Bella, Michael would not be where he is today. 

I knew her story deserved and needed to be shared so she could help others around the world.

Michael having a drink from the firehose after fighting a grueling fire 

 

Bella's Dash helps people with anxiety disorders, changing and saving lives one dog and person at a time. 

 

For those who navigate anxiety disorders and love animals, it is widely known that a deep and endearing bond exists that is unbreakable between dogs and their humans. Bella's Dash and pack tales are a testimony to the power of love in healing. 

 

"Bellas Dash is a remarkable account of how dogs add love and joy to our lives, healing us in our darkest hours. The memoir shares unique, heart-warming stories that will have you laughing and tearing up; and shows how every dog is special." 
Lynn Mckenzie Canada 

 

Bella's Dash and tales from the pack is a legacy project to raise awareness, funds and serve both people and animals in need. 

 

With every pledge for Bella's Dash, we are donating 20% of net proceeds and 20% of all future Bella’s Dash book royalties to S.N.A.P. (Spay, Neuter and Prevention), Cortez Rescue and Outreach, Tobacco Valley Animal Shelter, and Team Humanity.

 

Although this is a book I never wanted to write, I’m so glad I did! And I am even more thrilled and grateful for the tales from the pack – other writers from around the world who had powerful stories to share about their dogs as well.

Initially, anxiety, grief, self-doubt, and trepidation kept me from picking up the pen. But there was no getting around it. And after much soul searching, research and volunteering, it was time to write Bella's story. Bella and her pack of tales give new meaning to hope. 

Although Bella's Dash is a story born out of a tragedy to help both dogs and humans, it is also a story about the power and purpose of dogs in our lives. 

 

And here we are, all paws in. 

And we need YOU! 

 

My book, Bella's Dash, is a critical component in the kick-off of Team Bella, the legacy project. 

Bella's Dash and pack tales is a book that will leave you cheering, laughing, and at times crying. It’s about the passion, purpose, and power that animals have in our lives. 

Bella rescued us and mended the broken pieces. 

And we know from the early reviews that Bella's Dash is pawsitively needed. 

 

"Jo Dibblee writes a masterpiece about dogs and their pack members, us humans."             Bernadette Anderson – Reader Favorites  

 

As much as anxiety and stress are a part of life, they don't have to rule life. Bella's Dash shares through stories, the impact dogs have in our lives. 

Bella's Dash will educate, empower, impact, and most importantly, save lives and inspire readers to support this legacy.  

 

"I thoroughly enjoyed every page of Jo Dibblee's story of rescuing Bella, as she tells of how Bella ends up rescuing her and Michael during the dark times of their P.T.S.D. and A.S.D. I like what Dibblee says: 'that Bella met us where we were and took us someplace new.”  Joy Hannabass – USA

 

By contributing to this campaign at any level, you will:

  • Launch the Legacy of Bella's Dash 
  • Support animals rescue, shelters, and outreach programs
  • Sustain the critical work of spay and neuter clinics (S.N.A.P.) to prevent more unwanted puppies and abandoned dogs
  • Help share a vital legacy project with the world about the healing, hope, and transformation of humans and their dogs.
  • Empower those who navigate anxiety disorders and stress by providing a healthy, holistic, and more loving approach to health and wellness

 

Most importantly, you will save lives - dogs and humans, as we are giving 20% net proceeds from every donation to Cortez Rescue and Outreach, SNAP (Spay, Neuter and Prevention) Tobacco Valley Animal Shelter, and Team Humanity.

         

What's not to love? It's Win. Win. Win! 

 

Bella's Dash chronicles the unique bond, healing power, and unwavering love shared between dogs and humans.

 

Book Description 

Afraid and weak, an abandoned mama dog and her six-pack of wee pups are in dire need. Bella, a tenacious furball, is destined for great things, though she doesn't know it yet. It isn't long before she chooses her humans: a retired firefighter and his wife, a former witness in protection, who themselves are searching for the missing piece of their hearts. Bella's imprint touches all who know her during her short journey through the world. 

 

You'll cry, cheer and laugh your way through the profound emotional impacts that lead to the transformation from grief and trauma to joy and health. Bella's Dash and the pack is a collection of true stories about the power and purpose of adopting the otherwise forgotten while gaining immeasurable love and hope. 

 

"Jo Dibblee's book, Bella's Dash, is Bella's story. But it's more than that. It's a sharing of other pack stories, for dogs are pack animals, and all of their stories need to be shared. The author speaks from the heart as she shares Bella's stories as well as stories about other rescues. She speaks profoundly of our role as humans in this pack-animal scenario. She makes us challenge the concept that we are the leader of the pack, but, perhaps, dogs really do know best.”

-Jane Orford - Readers’ Favorites

 

What We Need - YOU! What You Get

Your generosity will be rewarded and greatly appreciated! When you contribute, here's what you can expect:

  • Our deepest gratitude, mine, and all the not-for-profit causes, regardless of pledge level. 
  • Every pledge you make matters and counts. With your commitment and support, we can donate more.   
  • We have pledge levels from donations to multiple books. Choose the perk that most interests you. An e-book (PDF) starts at $15 and we have levels offering up to ten books.
  • For every pledge above $15, you get a digital copy (PDF) to keep or give away to a friend, acknowledgment of your support, and a virtual Team Bella Badge. 
  • For every pledge of support over $49, you get an author inscribed and Oscar pawdagraphed 1st edition paperback copy, a digital copy (PDF), Team Bella badge, and personal recognition.
  • For every pledge of support from $89, you get a limited 1st edition hardcopy that is hand-numbered,  author inscribed, and Oscar Pawdagraphed,  a digital copy (PDF), Team Bella Badge, and personal recognition.
  • The more you pledge, the more the perks and the more lives you will be saving. 
  • You will get exclusive access to your digital copy (PDF) and the books before anyone else.
  • All hardcover copies are part of a limited-edition print run and will be hand-numbered, personally inscribed, and Oscar pawdagraphed. They are ONLY available through this campaign.

 

How will my contribution be spent?

The cost to produce a quality black and white printed book is 15K.

Bella's Dash is unique as the book has pictures of all the pack members.

I have invested 8k to date; as we’re now proceeding to production, the costs increase exponentially.

Our tier-one goal is to raise $10K for the project. A portion (20% net) of every pledge is set aside for donation - to our four non-for-profits. Beyond this, we need funding to help cover and recoup book production costs, such as cover design and editing, video production, illustrations, photography, perks, shipping, and marketing. Indiegogo takes a cut of every contribution, too.  

 

Campaign Goals

Three Tiers of Hope:

  • Tier 1: $10k e-book, paperback, hardcover. 20% net donation kicks off Bella's Legacy project and equally donates to S.N.A.P. (Spay, Neuter and Prevention), Cortez, Tobacco Valley Animal Shelter, and Team Humanity 
  • Tier 2: 18K We will add an audiobook and donate another net 20%. We will also supply books for not-for-profit fundraising. Additional funds will be equally distributed to S.N.A.P.  Cortez, Tobacco Valley Animal Shelter, and Team Humanity  
  • Tier 3: 25K Legacy Projects will launch at S.N.A.P., Cortez Rescue and Outreach, Tobacco Valley Animal Shelter, and Team Humanity ongoing donating of net 20%. Supporting ongoing critically important outreach work. 

We can offer the bonus funding at the $89 level and higher after 10K. 

More importantly, for every softcover and hardcover perk pledged and purchased at those levels - you'd also be donating and saving lives (at no extra cost to you).

 

Risks & Challenges

We are all in, so worry not! I've got a great team of professionals on my publishing team, and we're carrying the book to the finish line. 

If the campaign doesn't reach its goal, the manuscript is written and ready, and we are moving forward on sending to distribution. This project is far too important. And some adjustments will help ensure your contributor awards arrive on schedule. 

One of the most significant risks is the shipping costs of perks within each pledge purchase level. I have addressed this by building shipping costs into the campaign.

 

Team Members who are carrying the project to the finish line:

Tellwell Books: Assisted self-publishing from conception and production to distribution

Cover Design: Josh Aldrich, graphic artist, idreamdigital.com

Assistant Cover Designer: Krystal Eve Roque, print and graphic design 

Illustrator: M. Rosario Martinez, creation and continuity of message

Website Designer: Josh Aldrich, idreamdigital.com

Videographer: Ricardo Madrazo, digital storyteller

Photography: Julie Shipman Photography, Sponsor and creator of Pawsitive Greetings! 

Editor: Jen Violi, substantive editing  

Crowdfunding Consultant: Kim Duke, Kim Duke Writes.com

Project Manager: Atheena Carilla, author guide and flow expert

Interior and Production: Jomar Evidientes, interior formatting and layout

 

 

Let's make Bella's Dash a legacy of hope and inspiration. Become a Team Bella Member

Back the book, get rewarded, help this legacy launch, and save lives.

We can pawsitively do this. Anything is pawsible when we work together.

 

The Impact of Bella's Legacy

Sadly, animal abuse and neglect are rampant throughout the world despite the many who dedicate their lives to prevention, protection, rescue, and teaching. As I write this, 190 dogs are waiting to find their forever homes, as well as the countless dogs needing to be spayed and neutered. 

Both Cortez Rescue and Outreach and Tobacco Valley Animal Rescue work tirelessly to find homes for the abandoned and unwanted but they can’t do it alone – they need our help.

S.N.A.P., a phenomenal organization that is an independent, non-profit organization in Los Barriles, Mexico, performs FREE sterilization clinics for dogs and cats to the Mexican Community. 

Spaying or neutering is the first step in preventing the overpopulation of dogs and cats who become strays who are not cared for and are unwanted.  

This graphic tells the story of overpopulation. Based on one female and one male. 

I have had the privilege of adopting the forgotten and abandoned throughout my life, sadly though, there are so many beautiful dogs waiting to find their forever homes, but they never do. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't make a financial pledge? Help spread the word about this campaign. Use the share tools above and start supporting Cortez Rescue and Outreach, S.N.A.P. (Spay, Neuter, and Prevention), Tobacco Valley Animal Shelter, and Team Humanity Baja. 

At the top of the campaign page, you’ll see the "share" buttons. Click on the "chain" icon to get a custom link just for you. Please DO NOT use the URL in the browser window as it will not work for tracking purposes, and I won't be able to track you and your kindness.

Copy that link and paste it on your social media, email it to a friend, or text an animal lover you know and invite them to join in and be part of Bella's Legacy.

Every time someone clicks the link you sent and backs the project; you get one entry!

And please tag me using #bellasdash to acknowledge your kindness and help spread the project. 

Other Tags:

Instagram - @bellasdash @jodibblee  #BellasDashBook   #BellasDashLegacy

Facebook -  @jodibblee @bellasdash  #BellasDashBook   #BellasDashLegacy 

 

About Jo and Michael Dibblee:

Jo Dibblee is a professional speaker and author of several international award-winning bestselling books, beginning with Frock Off: Living Undisguised. Jo spent 35 years in hiding as a key witness in a murder investigation. Through it all, she remained hopeful that one day she would be free. Jo believes Bella and writing helped untangle and heal her. The trauma of both A.S.D. and P.T.S.D. were at times debilitating, but she never gave up. 

Jo has written several books; all have been international bestsellers. Jo's memoir, Frock Off: Living Undisguised, has been awarded internationally multiple times in True Crime and Inspiration categories. It is Jo's true story of being in hiding while in witness protection for 35 years.

Michael Dibblee is a retired firefighter. He served as a first responder and professional firefighter, including Dive Rescue Specialist, for 30 years. Occupational trauma caused P.T.S.D. and unhealthy coping mechanisms. Through healing, Michael now manages his P.T.S.D. and lives a happy, healthy, and joyful life.

 

Dedication

Bella's Dash is dedicated to all first responders, military, medical personnel, and all who have endured trauma; to those who work tirelessly helping find forever homes for rescue dogs; and of course, to Bella, who rescued us. 

Dianna Bowes believed in this project wholeheartedly and contributed as part of her legacy. She created beautiful prints and custom artwork for the project during chemo. Sadly, Dianna passed before the project was completed, but we know she is overseeing and cheering on the project. 

What's Next?

Stay tuned for our upcoming book launches, in the fall of 2021. And here's a little secret in 2022, we will be launching Brave Bold Bella, a children's book.

story:
How do I participate?

Here you get the opportunity to pre-order the book "From Tierra del Fuego" by Swedish naturalist and polar explorer Otto Nordenskjöld from 1898, by selecting your perk (book package) from the menu on the right. Click on each perk/ category to see what is included.

PHILANTHROPY: YOU WILL HELP US GIFT BOOKS TO LOCAL ENTITIES FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES

Summary

The project consists of the translation of a book of great historical importance from the original Swedish language, into Spanish and English for a wider audience to enjoy. Today only a small population of Swedish speaking people have access to all the extremely valuable information held within the pages of the 1898 edition of this book.

I have in my possession a very important book that describes a scientific journey to a then greatly unknown territory: a territory wrapped in mystique and solitude. This book, even though it is now an antiquity, is written in a very accessible language and describes people that are no longer here and places that still are. Reading this book gives insight to a very decisive point in Patagonian history while the scenes and settings are, if not the same, then very similar to today. The essence and spirit of Patagonia is very well captured in the book and will be recognizable to anyone who has already been here or to those who are about to visit.

My name is Dorthe Beldal, and I am presenting this project to you, to give you the opportunity to become part of a meaningful process filled with passion and wonderful people. I am a Scandinavian in Patagonia and with this project I am paying a personal debt I promised myself a long time ago. I need to make the content of this book available where it really matters; in the region where the exploration took place 120 years ago. I am making a dream come true.

This project is about bringing history to life. It is about creating a local impact;  about learning and understanding our past, about empowering the Patagonian Traveller but also about bringing a unique and important historical person back to life.

The Author: Otto Nordenskjöld

In 1895 a very young, Swedish scientist took the mature decision of taking upon himself a sub-polar expedition to an unknown land. Without a grand invasive expedition, he arrived and stayed for 2 years while roaming and exploring the interior region of Tierra del Fuego and Patagonia. He was intrigued by many unanswered scientific questions. Otto brought to us several important contributions during his academic career in the Antarctic and Sub Antarctic Environments. One might argue he changed the world:

  • He was the first scientist to venture inland in Tierra del Fuego & Patagonia.
  • He was the first white man – probably the first man at all – to look upon the Dickson Glacier in Torres del Paine National Park in Chile – and then giving it its name.
  • He was the one that brought the strange piece of (Mylodon) fur found in a cave in Ultima Esperanza to Buenos Aires and thereby sparking scientific interest in the unknown territory.
  • Later he brought with him a wooden cabin on his 1901 Antarctic Expedition. This cabin is still present on Snow Hill, today converted into a small Antarctic Museum.
  • He discovered fossils on the frozen continent that proved a previous connection to the South American Continent and thereby fathering the plate tectonic theory.

The Impact

We are working for this translation project to have a social impact. We need to bring this information to those that really need it. All this important information that has been hidden away in a foreign language needs to be delivered to where it belongs.

When reaching our first goal, we will have additionally 300 copies in Spanish. The Spanish version will be given to local libraries and schools so as to create a free and accessible knowledge base throughout the territory.

YOU WILL HELP US GIFT BOOKS TO LOCAL ENTITIES FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES

How is the project being carried out?: Teamwork

Process:

The book will pass through our hands several times to ensure a translation as close to the original as possible. We want the contemporary journey to be as close to the original. We are a team of professionals - who are driven by our passion and love for this remote territory - bringing together our knowledge and professions to offer this piece of history to the world.

What We Need & What You Get

We are advancing on our journey according to these Milestones:

January 2021: Spanish Version: 100%

February 2021: English Version 100%

March + April 2021: Editing, Work on Pictures, Prologue & Introduction

May 2021: PRINT & SHIPPING

Accomplishments to date:

Translation from Swedish: 72 %

Translation to Spanish: 37 %

Translation to English: 5 %

Stretch goal #1 is EUR 15,000 for the translation in 2 languages, editing, print & shipping

Salary (translation and editing): 6.500 Euros **

Print in two languages & shipping to wherever you are: 8.500 Euros

WE HAVE CHOSEN NOT TO COMPROMISE THE QUALITY OF THE BOOK IN ANYWAY. WE ARE WORKING TO BRING HISTORY TO LIFE WITH A LONG-LASTING IMPACT.

** Initially this was a philanthropic project that we, the executers of the project, gave our word and agreed on carrying out voluntarily in our spare time. However, as the process advances and the world is changing, it has become increasingly clear, that incorporating a translation salary in the project, is the only right thing to do. The entire team are employed in tourism with a very complicated season ahead and time spent on this project is even more valuable, as the team are taking their own time away from activities that help them obtain work in other industries.

Stretch goal #2 is EUR 22,000 for a true treasure hunt to take place

A research trip will be set up through the Nórdica Foundation in Patagonia, Chile!

Upon visiting the official Otto Nordenskjold Archieves on two occasions in the library of Gothenburg University in Sweden, we detected something odd: all the photos in this book (and there are many) are nowhere to be found. Non-existent. Some of these photos are copies or drawings, but many are of the personnel of the expedition. Could the expedition have taken place without a photographic register? It is possible but very unlikely. Otto even makes reference several times in the book of taking a photo. Somewhere in the world there exists an extremely valuable treasure.

If we achieve our first stretch goal all additional funds will be used to set up a true global treasure hunt. We already have a list of ideas of where to search that includes locations in Scandinavia and South America. How can this treasure contribute today? Imagine what an 1895 landscape photo can add of value to a context that is much younger: Patagonia and Tierra del Fuego do not have records of their natural elements that go very far back in time. This means that it is very difficult to read the impact of climate change, for instance, as we are short of reliable information to create models of the glacier’s movements. Now imagine finding a photo of a glacier that can provide information of its state 120 years ago.

Risks & Challenges

The slight risk of not making our goal exists. However as this a project that is born in our hearts, we are committed to the task of bringing this work to the world. Should we not make our goal, we will respect your purchase and perks anyway by seeking alternative funding - maybe, but hopefully not, on the expence of our salary and the philanthropic part of the project.

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to you, the backer. This risk is eliminated by building into the campaign the mailing and shipping costs of your copies to you within each pre-order tier.

We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as the book hits each key milestone and is published. You will know when the copies of the book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to make a contribution I understand and appreciate you stopping by! 

I would greatly appreciate your help in sharing this Pre-sale Campaign via Indiegogo (from the top of the page) with your friends, family and network.

THANK YOU FOR BRINGING HISTORY BACK TO LIFE

How do I participate?
Here you get the opportunity to pre-order the book "From Tierra del Fuego" by Swedish naturalist and polar explorer Otto Nordenskjöld from 1898, by selecting your perk (book package) from the menu on the right. Click on each perk/ category to see what is included.

Summary
The project consists of the translation of a book of great historical importance from the original Swedish language, into Spanish and English for a wider audience to enjoy. Today only a small population of Swedish speaking people have access to all the extremely valuable information held within the pages of the 1898 edition of this book.
I have in my possession a very important book that describes a scientific journey to a then greatly unknown territory: a territory wrapped in mystique and solitude. This book, even though it is now an antiquity, is written in a very accessible language and describes people that are no longer here and places that still are. Reading this book gives insight to a very decisive point in Patagonian history while the scenes and settings are, if not the same, then very similar to today. The essence and spirit of Patagonia is very well captured in the book and will be recognizable to anyone who has already been here or to those who are about to visit.
My name is Dorthe Beldal, and I am presenting this project to you, to give you the opportunity to become part of a meaningful process filled with passion and wonderful people. I am a Scandinavian in Patagonia and with this project I am paying a personal debt I promised myself a long time ago. I need to make the content of this book available where it really matters; in the region where the exploration took place 120 years ago. I am making a dream come true.
This project is about bringing history to life. It is about creating a local impact;  about learning and understanding our past, about empowering the Patagonian Traveller but also about bringing a unique and important historical person back to life.

story:
Short Summary

Hi! I'm a healing artist, and an artistic healer. I grew up in Xi'an and Shanghai, before studying abroad and working/living in the United States and Spain. 

I wrote my first suicide note when I was in my second boarding school. My self-worth was as low as dirt. Bullying from various schools that I constantly had to fit in, divorced family with depression, the co-unconciousness of the society... I wetted my bed until I was about 10 or 11 year's old. My blurred speech issues were giving away my social anxiety...and all that went unnoticed. I felt deeply worthless, inferior, and disgusted with myself due to my lack of self-love.

I was troubled by my guilt and shame on a daily basis, as a young Chinese lady.

The idea of being an outsider became more significant to me when I grew up and became a foreigner. With all of those baggages that bled into my first few relationships, my first job (selling Xerox copiers in Northern Virginia and failing at it), mixed with my perpetual self-esteem issues, I somehow managed to flourish and grow.

How? I did everything in my power to find my inner resources, to recognize the compassion that I did experience growing up, to become a giver instead of a taker. I had talk therapy, group therapy, spiritual healing, primal twice-born...I mainly channeled this will to heal into my entrepreneurial projects, because I believe that the real growth happens in the daily life. 

My relationship with my roots have changed, once I realized that I needed to "return to origin", a Taoism principle. I began to embrace my imperfection and started to celebrate who I am, as who I already have been.

Struggle up, shall we? Experimentatively heal, shall we?

I became a life coach, group facilitator, psychodrama practitioner, and created my own Guang Healing project that involves Tibetan Singing Bowl and energy work...serendipitously, my wounds are letting me heal others.

I want to tell my honest story and show you how I healed and transformed my trauma, as well as how I heal others...mostly, how I cope and turn my trauma into fuel...or a source of clean energy.

This would be a digital art book about that, with my naked heart.

What I Need & What You Get

You will get a digital art book. :D It's full of inspirations and self-love related healing tools. A sense of humor can always be found in my attempt to heal. So, this could be quite heart-felt but amusing. This book could inspire you to self-heal and self-coach, and to experiment something new with even more grit and courage in your life.

You can also choose to get a private recorded sound healing session, or a few personal therapeutic coaching sessions. :D

The money raised will contribute to the production of the digital art book and paying for the tuition of the last year of my graduate school in psychodrama therapy. If we raise plenty, then we can try to make it on print in the future too. No promises for that one yet! Let's see. :D

The Impact

You will make a difference:

  • Help other people heal, especially people who are hurting and feeling desperate.
  • Help other people grow, especially those thriving but finding it hard to believe in themselves
  • Help me keep on doing crazy but authentic content 

Risks & Challenges

You might find my honesty in my content offensive if you came from background like my parents. The content is somewhat gender-fluid; sexuality will be addressed. Again, it might upset you if you were my parents.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are struggling with money...then there are other ways to support my cause:

  • Follow me on my website YokyYu.com or Instagram: Yoky_Yu and if you see any healing content, feel free to pass it on...

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Thrill seekers,

If you have a habit of chasing horror, then I invite you to get your fix.

My name is Kassandra Dick and I am responsible for this chilling tale. It is my first novel, but I've been writing scary stories since I was a child. In fact, I'm even plotting out a children's scary story book for next year.

This year, I present to you, Habit. The story of a paramedic in Vancouver, BC, who finds himself sinking into addictions and tries to rise above them, only to realize there's always more to our habits than what meets the eye.

I want to formally warn all my loved ones that this may not be the story you're looking for, but I appreciate your support.

For everyone else, Enjoy.

 

Special Thanks:

Joel Macleod at Dream State Design, for this incredible cover

Merielle Kazakoff, my editor and friend

Bert Van Cleemputte, my unsuspecting beta-reader

 

Thank You Everyone

For taking the time to like my posts, and to share the link to this Pre-Launch with any sick-minded friends you know who'd enjoy a spot of horror.

The e-book will be available on Amazon and Kindle July 31, 2021.

If I reach my goal (even if I don't), I'll be working less on external projects and putting more energy into writing and publishing MORE BOOKS!

Not all my future stories will be horror either. If you like Crime Stories, Sci-Fi, Fantasy, Speculative Fiction and Poetry, be sure to tune in to my Instagram page to hear more about upcoming projects.

story:
About The Book

My Low Carb Life explores the process of how I changed my life and my health by losing more than 130 pounds.

My name is Keith McDaniel and I wrote this book in order to share with others what I have learned about safe and healthy weight loss by following a low carb eating plan. In My Low Carb Life, I not only tell the story of my life-long struggle with being overweight but I also write about how, at the age of 58, I decided to once and for all take control of my health. I write about what I discovered that worked for me and offer some advice for others who might choose to do the same.

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will relate to my story and realize that it is never too late to make a change in your life and health that will have an impact on the rest of your life. I am not a doctor, medical professional or nutritionist, I am just an average guy who found a way to lose a lot of weight and keep it off in a safe and healthy manner.

In this book, you'll hear stories such as...

  • How, after a lifetime of struggling with my weight, I found the determination to make a permanent change in the way I eat.
  • Tips and suggestions, from my experience, on how to maintain a safe and healthy diet.
  • 50 of my favorite low carb recipes.

My Low Carb Life  is a nonfiction book that speaks to those who, once and for all, want to find a way to control their weight and make a change that lasts a lifetime.

 

What I Need & What You'll Get

I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:

  • The editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in August 2021.
  • The cover design of my book. (The mockups you see currently are a placeholder!)
  • The layout design for the interior of my book (physical copy, ebook formats).
  • The copy editing for my book to polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication.
  • The launch & promotion efforts for my book when I ultimately publish this Summer.

The original funding goal is set at $4,000 at which point I will have the costs covered to publish a paperback and ebook. 

I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:

  • Your name will appear in the Acknowledgments section of my book.
  • You will receive early access to the Introduction and other excerpts from my book, with the opportunity to review them and give me early feedback.
  • You will have the opportunity to be involved in selecting my cover and title.
  • And much more!

 

About the Author

Keith McDaniel is an award-winning documentary filmmaker and oral historian. For more than 20 years, Keith has been engaging audiences with the stories of the people, places and events that have significance in American history. His films have been screened for audiences around the world and have garnered numerous favorable reviews and recognition.

But, five years ago when he went to a physical with his doctor, Keith realized it was time for him to take control of his weight and his life. He used the same skills he had developed as a filmmaker - research, study, etc. -  to tackle the biggest threat to his health and his future.

After formulating a way to eat that was not only healthy but effective in losing weight, Keith lost more than 130 pounds and has kept if off since. When he shared his progress on social media, Keith had many comments and questions about how he lost the weight. So, he decided to write a book about his journey so that others might benefit from the things he has learned about losing weight and living a healthy life.

 

International Preorders

Due to shipping costs, I will only be able to mail physical copies to those of you located in the US. If you are not based in the US, please support me with the e-book option ($15 option) instead . Thank you  so much for your support!
 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by including the cost of mailing and shipping the signed copies into each pre-order tier.

We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as to when my book will publish. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Please share my pre-sale campaign on Facebook and Twitter with your friends, family and network. 

You can easily share my Pre-Sale Campaign Page via Indiegogo at the top of the page.

Please share my book with 5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it via text or direct message on social media.

Thank you so much for of all of your love and support!

story:
My name is Adam Misner, and I'm an author looking to put a wholesome love story out into the world. Often I run into stories with love triangles that sap my enthusiasm for the couple, cheating or other drama that bums me out, and melancholic endings from writers afraid their story wont be seen as deep if they write a happy ending. I wanted to rebel against that trend and make something happy. If I've done my job right, my story should linger in the back of your mind and put a smile on your face, from time to time, when you remember a moment from it.

 

The story begins with Simon, a skinny, blonde, twenty something who's reeling from a rough breakup. To cope, he gets himself to Disney World and mindlessly rides a roller coaster there, again and again, doing his best to keep himself from thinking. Through the crowd he's noticed by Morrigan, a ride attendant. She's a goth chick born a thousand miles away, with very little in common with him, but she can recognize a kindred spirit.

 

 

What's the money for?

The book's already written, and in its final stages of editing. Barring a bolt from Zeus, I will publish this book, hence the flexible funding. The money is meant to cover the cost of art and printing. If the goal isn't met I'll still have the books printed out of pocket.

Don't take this to mean your contribution isn't valuable, however. What the funding goal doesn't represent is the value of the many many hours spent over two years to write this book. I spent those hours because I love to write, and I'll spend many more for the same reason, but your financial support will help me  to contribute more time to this fulfilling work and inspire me. Knowing that other people value and enjoy what I create, moves me deeply.

 

 

Other ways you can help,

If you can't contribute financially, it'd still be incredibly helpful if you'd spread the word. Even if you just know one friend who's on an IV drip of Hallmark movies, to get some positivity into their life, tell them about my book and I think you'd make the both of us very happy.
